newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Boeing-MDC merger best for industry - BA.
newsitem.headline: Boeing-MDC merger best for industry - BA.

text.p: The airline industry is expected to benefit from the merger between Boeing Co and McDonnell Douglas Corp, British Airways plc (BA) chairman Sir Colin Marshall said on Thursday.
"The merger means only two huge civil aircraft manufacturers after this, the other being Airbus Industrie," Marshall told reporters.
"There will be competition in different categories between the two giant aircraft manufacturers and we (the airline industry) can assume getting the best terms," he said.

Marshall was addressing a news conference in Shah Alam, an industrial city north of Kuala Lumpur, where he was visiting the Malaysian operations of Britain's Inchcape plc of which he is also chairman.
Boeing and McDonnell announced on Sunday they would merge in a stock swap to create the world's largest aircraft manufacturer and a giant player in civil aviation, aerospace and defence.
Marshall said he did not expect any major operational changes at Boeing and McDonnell Douglas after the merger.

"I think McDonnell will continue manufacturing civilian aircraft even after the merger, only that they'd be with Boeing," Marshall. "This means stronger competition for Airbus to produce better planes."

Airbus is a consortium made up of French state-owned Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale, British Aerospace plc, Germany's Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG (DASA) and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA (CASA) of Spain.
Boeing is the world leader in civilian aircraft, followed by Airbus. McDonnell Douglas has lagged behind in this sector but is a powerful force in military jets.

Responding to a question on British Airways, Marshall said negotiations were still on for the carrier to buy the new Boeing 747-600, although it was uncertain yet whether it would be a launch customer.
"From our standpoint, the issue is working its way to the decision process and if that (decision) coincides with the manufacturer's launch plans, so be it," he said.
